content.text: The student suspends a mass \(m = 100\mathrm{g}\) from the spring
She measures, and records in Table 1.1, the stretched length \(l\) of the spring, as indicated in Fig. 1.1
Describe **two** techniques for measuring the length of the spring, to ensure an accurate reading. You may draw a diagram
She repeats step (a) for values of \(m = 200 \text{g}\), \(m = 300 \text{g}\), \(m = 400 \text{g}\) and \(m = 500 \text{g}\). Her readings are shown in Table 1.1
Plot a graph of \(l / \mathrm{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(m / \mathrm{g}\) (x-axis)
Start the axes from the origin (0, 0)
Draw a best-fit straight line. The line might not go through the origin
Use your graph to determine the length \(l_0\) of the spring with no load on it
On Fig. 1.2, measure the stretched length \(l_{\chi}\) of the spring
Use the graph and your reading from (d)(i), to determine the mass \(m_{\chi}\) of object \(\mathbf{X}\). Show clearly on the graph how you obtained your answer
An object \(\mathbf{X}\) is suspended from the spring
Two students measure the mass of another object using the same method and apparatus. One student records the mass as \(132.6\mathrm{g}\). The other student records the mass as \(130\mathrm{g}\)
State and explain which answer has the more suitable number of significant figures for this experiment
statement
explanation
A student investigates the behaviour of a spring, and then uses the spring to determine the mass of an object
The apparatus is shown in Fig. 1.1
Record room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) shown on the thermometer in Fig. 2.1
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)
Describe **one** technique used to ensure that the room temperature reading is as accurate as possible
The student pours \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A and records the temperature \(\theta\) at time \(t = 0\)
He records, in Table 2.1, the temperature of the water in the beaker every 30 s
The student repeats the procedure for beaker B
It is important that the temperatures are recorded at exactly every 30 s
Describe a technique which will make it easier for the student to do that
beaker A with insulation beaker B without insulation
Write a conclusion stating whether the insulation affects the rate of cooling of the water. Justify your answer by referring to values from the results
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{1}\) during the first half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use the readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{90}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at times \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\)
Include the unit
Calculate the average cooling rate \(x_{2}\) during the second half of the experiment for the water in beaker B. Use the readings for beaker B from Table 2.1 and the equation:
where \(T = 90 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_{90}\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures of the water in beaker B at \(t = 90 \text{s}\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Include the unit
A student suggests that, for this type of experiment, the temperature of the water in each beaker at time \(t = 0\) must be the same for the comparison to be fair
Use your answers from (d)(i) and (d)(ii) to explain whether this is necessary
A student wants to eliminate, from the comparison, any thermal energy lost from the surface of the water
Suggest a change to the equipment which will do that
Suggest what effect this change will have on the cooling rates of the water in beaker A and beaker B
A student investigates the effect of insulation on the cooling of water
He uses the apparatus shown in Fig. 2.1
Beaker A is covered with material that is a thermal insulator
Beaker B is identical to beaker A but has no insulation
Draw a normal to point \(\mathbf{N}\), extending above \(\mathbf{AB}\). Label the upper end of the normal with the letter \(\mathbf{L}\)
The student draws line **EN** as shown in Fig. 3.1
On Fig. 3.1, measure the acute angle \(\theta\) between the lines **LN** and **EN**
An acute angle is an angle of less than \(90^{\circ}\)
The student places a transparent block \(\mathbf{ABCD}\) near the centre of the ray-trace sheet as indicated in Fig. 3.1
Measure distance \(d\) between pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\)
State whether the two pins are a suitable distance apart for accurate ray tracing. Explain your answer
statement
explanation
The student places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line **EN** as shown in Fig. 3.1
The student views the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through the block

He places two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) so that pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) all appear exactly one behind the other
Draw a line through \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) . Extend this line to meet **CD**
Label the point at which this line meets **CD** with the letter **F**. Label the lower end of this line with the letter **G**
Extend line **EN** to approximately \(5\mathrm{cm}\) below line **CD**
Label the point at which this line crosses **CD** with the letter **H**. Label the lower end of this line with the letter **J**
Measure the acute angle \(\alpha\) between lines **CD** and **GF**
\(\alpha =\)
Measure the acute angle \(\beta\) between lines **CD** and **JH**
\(\beta =\)
A student suggests that angle \(\alpha\) should be equal to angle \(\beta\)
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your answer by reference to values from your results
statement
justification
Describe two techniques to use in this type of experiment to ensure results are accurate
Suggest one reason why different students, all doing this experiment carefully, may not obtain identical results
A student investigates the refraction of light by a transparent block
The student's ray-trace sheet is shown full-size in Fig. 3.1
A student investigates the resistance of a wire
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how the length of a wire affects the resistance of the wire
Resistance \(R\) is calculated from the equation: \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
where \(V\) is the potential difference (p.d.) across the wire and \(I\) is the current in the wire
The apparatus available includes:
a selection of wires
a variable power supply
an ammeter
a voltmeter
In your plan:
list any additional apparatus needed
complete Fig. 4.1 to show a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the wire
explain briefly how to do the experiment, including the measurements to take so that the resistance can be determined
state the key variables to keep constant
draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
